block.p: Putin Takes Responsibility For Response to Sinking President Vladimir V. Putin moved to contain the political impact of the sunken submarine Kursk, taking responsibility on national television for what some Russians called a botched response to the incident. He said the defense minister and the fleet commander had offered their resignations, but they had been rejected.

Airliner Crashes in Gulf All 143 people aboard a Gulf Air Airbus A320 on a flight from Cairo were killed when the plane crashed in the Persian Gulf while trying to land in Bahrain.

Iraqi Denounces Inspections Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz denounced a new United Nations weapons inspection commission and vowed Iraq would never cooperate with inspectors. Mr. Aziz's comments in Baghdad came as the commission convened a two-day meeting at the United Nations to review new monitoring operations.

U.N. Peacekeeping Proposal A panel of international experts recommended that the United Nations peacekeeping department, criticized for a series of problems in recent years, be enlarged and professionalized, with intelligence-gathering functions that were essentially forbidden during the cold war.

Waiver for Colombia Defended President Clinton, addressing his decision to sign a waiver freeing $1.3 billion in anti-drug aid, said Colombia was improving on human rights even though the government of Andres Pastrana had not met all conditions imposed by Congress.
Indonesian Cabinet Revamped President Abdurrahman Wahid unveiled a revamped cabinet in a move to revitalize his faltering administration and tackle acute social and economic woes.
West Timor Aid Suspended The United Nations high commissioner for refugees suspended aid operations in West Timor following the beating of three relief workers by pro-Indonesia militiamen.
Bid to Preserve Newton Archive Cambridge University opened a fund-raising campaign to keep the papers of its alumnus Sir Isaac Newton in Britain and out of the hands of outside buyers and collectors.

Elected Official Cited For Using Aides to Baby-Sit The Massachusetts State Ethics Commission found that Lt. Gov. Jane Swift, a Republican who won her office in 1998 less than three weeks after bearing her first child, had violated ethics rules by having two aides baby-sit away from the State House. The panel has the power to fine or reprimand her.

Airline Acts to Cut Delays United Airlines has issued an operational emergency order requiring mechanics at Chicago, Denver, Indianapolis, Los Angeles and Washington to work overtime if asked, to help avert delays and cancellations.

Storm Weakens in Caribbean Tropical Storm Debby lost momentum as it spun westward across the island of Hispaniola and headed toward the northern coast of Cuba. It was expected to weaken even more before threatening Florida or moving into the Gulf of Mexico.

Reno Discusses Gore Decision Attorney General Janet Reno portrayed her decision not to name a special prosecutor to investigate Vice President Al Gore's statements about his role in 1996 fund-raising activities as a one that cleared him only of making false statements in an April 18 interview with investigators. She said the four-year inquiry into fund-raising would continue.

Taking a Step on Warming Texas' three natural resource commissioners, all appointees of Gov. George W. Bush, said global warming was a serious problem and that the state would explore ways to cut its emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases.

Rush to Certify Teachers A growing number of states and school districts are short-circuiting the usual route to teacher certification with crash courses that put new teachers in the classroom after as little as three weeks of training.

Summer School Promotions Two out of every three New York City students who showed up for summer school will be promoted to the next grade, even though only about 40 percent of those who took the end-of-summer reading and mathematics tests passed them.

Police Say Counselor Led Missing Boys to River The search continued for two teenage boys from a state psychiatric center who were swept away in the Hudson on Tuesday. Investigators said a counselor who had been warned to keep his charges out of the water led six boys to the river's edge, where three suddenly jumped in; one managed to get back to shore.

Alcohol Ban Is Eased Less than two weeks after the Giuliani administration announced a ban on alcohol sales along parade routes, city officials backed off a police proposal to end sales at street festivals. Alcohol sales will be allowed at the Feast of San Gennaro in Little Italy but the number of vendors will be cut in half. Organizers of other events complained of a double standard.

Rules for Stem Cell Research The National Institutes of Health issued rules that would let federally financed researchers work on cells derived from very early embryos. Abortion opponents condemned the action, which President Clinton defended, saying that as long as rigorous ethical standards are met, ''we cannot walk away from the potential to save lives and improve lives.''

Diabetes on Rise in U.S. The incidence of diabetes rose markedly from 1990 to 1998, especially Type 2, or adult onset diabetes, which represents up to 95 percent of cases and can be brought on by inactivity and weight gain. More than half of Americans are overweight.

Conflicting Hormone Findings A study found that estrogen replacement therapy does nothing to slow heart disease in women whose arteries are already partly blocked by the disease. But another study cited the therapy as a factor in the decline of heart disease among women.
The Ultimate 'Survivor' Richard Hatch, 39, a corporate trainer from Rhode Island, won the $1 million prize in the CBS series.

Home Heating Oil Prices Rise A decline in crude oil inventories sent home heating oil prices to their highest level in a decade, 95.61 cents a gallon for September delivery, up 5.26 cents, or 5.8 percent.
Amazon to Sell Cars Online Amazon.com, one of the world's largest online retailers, said it would begin a car-selling service today.
Maytag in Acquisition Talks The appliance maker was said to be negotiating to be acquired by Electrolux, the Swedish maker of Frigidaire refrigerators and other products, for nearly $4 billion.
More Phone Workers Settle Verizon and a union representing 35,000 employees in mid-Atlantic states settled an 18-day strike.
